Research article Electrochemical synthesis of biomass-derived aromatic N-heterocycles by using Ni-based hierarchical nanosheets catalysts Zhouyi Quan Writing – original draft Methodology Formal analysis Data curation 1 Wanling Xu Writing – original draft Methodology Formal analysis Data curation 1 Jinzhu Chen Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Supervision Project administration Methodology Investigation Funding acquisition ⁎ College of Chemistry and Materials Science, Jinan University, Guangzhou 511443, China College of Chemistry and Materials Science Jinan University Guangzhou 511443 China College of Chemistry and Materials Science, Jinan University, Guangzhou 511443, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 Z.Q. and W.X. contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract Electrochemical synthesis of biomass-derived aromatic N-heterocycles was achieved by using Ni-based electro catalysts with hierarchical nanosheets morphology. Electrochemical valorization of biomass to aromatic N-heterocycles is a pioneering field and an eco-friendly synthetic strategy. Herein, electro-oxidative cyclocondensations of biomass-based furoin with 1,2-phenylenediamines are developed for quinoxalines syntheses (16 examples) in 97∼80% yields by using Ni-based electro catalyst with KI as electrolyte and mediator. The electrocatalyst is developed as Ni-nanosheets densely assembled on a knitted carbon cloth with a hierarchical 3D-open network. The electrochemical furoin-to-quinoxaline transformation involves a tandem reaction of Ni-promoted I−-to-[I+] electro-oxidation, [I+]-induced furoin-to-furil oxidation, and furil/1,2-phenylenediamine cyclocondensation. The high performance of Ni catalyst is ascribed to its promotion effect on quick and selective I−-to-[I+] electro-oxidation, thus triggering a [I+]-mediated furoin oxidation. In contrast, the competitive reaction of direct 1,2-phenylenediamine oxidation is significantly suppressed on the anodic Ni surface. This research thus highlights a sustainable way for the productions of high value-added aromatic N-heterocycles by electro catalytic transformation of biomass-based compounds with earth-abundant transition-metal catalyst. Keywords Biomass Electrochemical synthesis Furfural Nickel electro catalyst Quinoxaline Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Extensive efforts have currently been devoted into construction of high-valued nitrogen-containing heterocyclic compounds (N-heterocycles) from renewable biomass [1–3], N-heterocycles are recurring building blocks in the drugs, pharmaceuticals, medicines, polymers, agrochemicals, dyes, textiles, and functional materials [4,5]. Therefore, biomass feedstock with versatile reactivity, chemical functionality, and renewable nature can extensively and sustainably extend N-heterocyclic chemistry. Among various N-heterocycles, quinoxalines have been considered as privileged and versatile structural scaffolds in medicinal chemistry, pharmaceutical agents, pharmacologically active compounds, agrochemicals and natural products [6–8]. Moreover, quinoxalines exhibit a diverse range of industrial applications in organic semiconductors, polymer light-emitting diodes (PLEDs), organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), organic solar cells, electroluminescent materials and fluorescent dyes [9–11]. Given their significance in pharmacy, chemistry as well as industry, various synthetic strategies have been developed to prepare quinoxalines. Generally, quinoxalines are synthesized through cyclocondensation of 1,2-dicarbonyl groups with 1,2-phenylenediamine, or oxidative cyclocondensation of α-hydroxyketones with 1,2-diamines [12–14]. The reported catalytic systems for cyclocondensation of 1,2-dicarbonyls with 1,2-phenylenediamine are generally based on acidic catalysts. While, oxidative cyclocondensations of α-hydroxyketones with 1,2-diamines are mainly limited to thermo-induced catalytic process, the resulting catalysts involve OMS-2 (manganese oxide) [15], FeCl3-morpholine [16], Cu(I) complex-KO t Bu [17], Au-nanoparticles (NPs)-K2CO3 [18], Ru/C [19], poly(4-vinylpyridine)-stabilized Pd NPs [20], Yb/NaY-morpholine [21], I2-DMSO [22], α-Zr(HPO4)2·H2O [23]. However, these developed synthetic methods usually show some inherent disadvantages, such as the need for high temperature to drive the reaction, additional addition of oxidant, use of expensive metal precursors and unsatisfactory yields. Therefore, the goal of this work is to develop an efficient and practical strategy for quinoxalines syntheses from biomass-based feedstocks. Li and co-workers recently reported one-pot synthesis of quinoxaline derivatives from lignin-based β-O-4 model compounds and 1,2-phenylenediamine (2a) by using KOH as a catalyst [24]. In this research, Fig. 1 a demonstrates a synthetic strategy to biomass-based quinoxaline by using furfural (5), a biomass-based platform molecule, as a feedstock. As a biomass-based vicinal diol, hydrofuroin (6) can be obtained by reductive coupling of 5; while, α-hydroxyketone of furoin (1a) can be readily synthesized by a direct coupling of 5. Aerobic oxidation of 1a or consecutive oxidation of 6 gives 1,2-diketone compound of furil (3a). Cyclocondensation of 2a with 3a yields biomass-based 2,3-di(2-furanyl)quinoxaline (4a). A directly oxidative cyclocondensation of 1a with 2a can also afford 4a in one pot. In contrast to the traditionally thermocatalytic process, electrochemical synthesis is particularly attractive by which electrons function as safe and green “reagents” to drive reduction or oxidation reactions without using hazardous redox chemicals [25]. For example, electrocatalytic reduction of oxalic acid to glycolic acid was recently investigated by using TiO2-nanotube array-based electrode material [26]. Moreover, reaction selectivity and yield can be readily controlled through reaction parameters such as electrode potential, circuit current, and electrode material (electrocatalyst) [27]. Finally, electrochemical oxidation can be carried out at ambient temperature under atmospheric pressure without using external oxygen. In this regard, catalytic electro-oxidation demonstrates a more sustainable synthetic strategy as electricity instead of chemical oxidant drives the reaction. Therefore, in most cases, electrochemical synthesis is associated with low energy consumption, safe issues, mild reaction conditions, and a broad substrate tolerance. In this research, electrochemical synthesis of 4a was thus developed via oxidative cyclocondensation of 1a with 2a in one-pot by a well-designed electrocatalyst. As one of important earth-abundant transition metals, Ni was recently reported as a versatile electrocatalyst for electro-oxidation of various organic substrates such as furfuryl alcohol [28], 5-(hydroxymethyl)furfural [29–31], glycerol [32,33], methanol [34–36], alcohol [37–39], cyclohexanol [40], ethylene glycol [41], hydrazine [42], amine [43] and urea [44–47]. Moreover, Ni-based electrocatalysts were investigated for dehydrogenation of N-heterocycles [48], chemo selective electro-oxidation of hydroxysteroids [49], and electro-oxidative cleavage of vicinal diols [50]. Generally, Ni‐based anodic electrocatalysts advantageously exhibit potential for electro-oxidation of organic substrates due to its in-situ formed Ni3+/Ni2+ and Ni2+/Ni0 redox couples. Moreover, in-situ formation and transformation of various Ni species such as Ni, Ni(OH)2, NiO and NiO(OH) on the electrode surface can efficiently control reaction selectivity [51]. Finally, readily formation of various Ni-based composites such as Ni-Fe, Ni-Co, Ni-Cu, Ni-Mo, Ni-Mn, nickel sulfide, nickel phosphide, nickel nitride and nickel boride further extend the reaction type, reaction selectivity, and substrate scope for a variety of electrochemical syntheses [52,53]. For example, NiFe electrocatalyst with hierarchical microflower morphology was recently reported by assembling ultrathin NiFe nanosheets on carbon fiber paper. The resulting NiFe catalyst can efficiently promote electrocatalytic oxidation of furfuryl alcohol into furoic acid with the in-situ generated surface NiOOH species as catalytic active site. Furthermore,Zou and co-workers recently investigated electro oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) over Ni3N electrocatalyst by using various operando and in-situ characterization techniques. The in-situ generated Ni2+δN(OH)ads species from the Ni3N surface-adsorbed hydroxyl group was identified as catalytic active site for the electro-oxidation of HMF [54]. Inspired by the above discussion, a Ni-based electrocatalyst (NiNS/CC, Fig. 1b) was well designed in this research by an in-situ growth of two-dimensional (2D) Ni nanosheets (NiNS) on a knitted carbon cloth (CC). The obtained NiNS/CC exhibited a three-dimensional (3D) open network with a hierarchical architecture, in which NiNS with a 2D morphology fully, densely and homogeneously covers every one-dimensional (1D) nanofiber of the CC in a highly cross-linked style. NiNS/CC can thus well take advantage of the excellent conductivity of CC. The thin-layered nanosheet morphology of NiNS may possess high specific surface area, can sufficiently and homogeneously expose its surface-active site. Accordingly, these ordered and hierarchical architecture can well provide porous channels for electron communication between NiNS and CC. As expected, the electrocatalyst NiNS/CC showed excellent activity for electrochemical synthesis of 4a (97% yield) via oxidative cyclocondensation of 1a with 2a (Fig. 1b). Moreover, a variety of biomass-based quinoxalines (16 examples) were readily achieved with the NiNS/CC in excellent to good yields (97∼80%). The NiNS/CC also exhibited excellent recyclability and stability in a consecutive eight-time recycling for the electrochemical synthesis of 4a. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and characterization methods Materials, hydrophilic modification of carbon cloth (CC), LSVs/CVs/OCP/EIS measurements, products analyses/calculations, and characterization methods were provided in the Supporting Information. 2.2 Preparation of catalyst 2.2.1 Preparation of NiO nanosheets on carbon cloth (NiONS/CC) In a typical synthetic procedure of NiONS/CC-2, urea (24 mmol), nickel chloride hexahydrate (6 mmol), ammonium fluoride (12 mmol) and deionized water (40 mL) were well mixed. The solution obtained was continuously ultrasonicated for 0.5 h. Then, the reaction solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave (100 mL) containing four pieces of modified and cleaned CC (1.0 cm × 1.0 cm). The autoclave was then sealed and heated for 6 h at 120 °C. After the autoclave was cooled to ambient temperature, the resulting nickel species decorated-CC was thoroughly washed by using absolute ethanol and deionized water several times, and then dried for 12 h at 60 °C in an oven. The obtained dried nickel species decorated-CC was further calcined at 450 °C for 2 h with the heating rate of 2 °C min−1 under an atmospheric N2 to give NiONS/CC-2. The Ni content in NiONS/CC-2 was 6.15 mg cm−2 according to inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) analysis. 2.2.2 Preparation of Ni nanosheets on carbon cloth (NiNS/CC) In a typical synthetic procedure of NiNS/CC-2, the obtained NiONS/CC-2 was calcined under an atmospheric H2/N2 (V H2 10%, 20 mL min−1) at 500 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 to give NiNS/CC-2 (3.53 mg cm−2). The synthetic procedure of NiNS/CC-1 (1.91 mg cm−2) and NiNS/CC-3 (5.67 mg cm−2) are almost the same with NiNS/CC-2 (3.53 mg cm−2) except that 3 mmol and 9 mmol NiCl2⋅6H2O were respectively used for NiNS/CC-1 and NiNS/CC-3 syntheses. For comparison purpose, NiNS/CC-0 sample was prepared with same synthetic procedure of NiNS/CC-2 without addition of NiCl2⋅6H2O. 2.3 Electrochemical test of electrode 2.3.1 Electrochemical test All electrochemical measurements were carried out by using an electrochemical workstation (CHI-760E). Electrochemical tests were initially measured in a standard three-electrode system in a CH3OH/H2O (8.0 mL/2.0 mL) solution by using NiNS/CC-2 as a working electrode, Pt sheet (1.0 × 1.0 cm2) as a counter electrode, Ag/AgCl as a reference electrode, and KI (40 mM) as electrolyte. All the reported potentials were calibrated relative to the silver chloride electrode (Ag/AgCl) in this research. The pH value during the reaction process of the electrocatalytic system is measured by a pH meter (LeiCi PHS-25) and the results were recorded in the Supporting Information (Table S1). LSV measurement was manually compensated for IR. Manual IR compensation follows the following formula, V ir = V 0 - i R ct where V ir , V 0 , i and R ct respectively represent the voltage after IR compensation, the original voltage, current density and the internal resistance of the solution. 2.4 Electrochemical synthesis of furil and quinoxalines In a typical procedure for 4a synthesis, 1a (20 mM), 2a (40 mM), KI (40 mM), MeOH (8.0 mL), and H2O (2.0 mL) were continuously loaded into a single-chamber electrolyser (20 mL). The experiment was performed in a two-electrode configuration by using NiNS/CC-2 as an anode and Pt as a cathode. A voltage of 2.0 V was input into the electrochemical system for 4 h with continuous electrolysis. After the reaction, the resulting reaction mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate, filtered by syringe filter and calibrated to 25 mL by using a volumetric flask. The obtained mixture was then analysed by GC and GC–MS to determine the 1a conversion and 3a/4a yields. In a typical procedure for 3a synthesis, 1a (20 mM), KI (40 mM), MeOH (8.0 mL), and H2O (2.0 mL) were continuously loaded into a single-chamber electrolyser (20 mL). The experiment was performed in a three-electrode configuration by using NiNS/CC-2 as a working electrode, Pt as a counter electrode and Ag/AgCl as a reference electrode. A potential of 1.0 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) was input into the electrochemical system for 4 h with continuous electrolysis. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterization of electrocatalyst In this research, an in-situ growth of NiO nanosheets (NiONS) on a knitted CC (denoted as NiONS/CC) was prepared as the precursor of NiNS/CC. The NiONS/CC was prepared by treatment of a mixture of nickel chloride hexahydrate, urea, ammonium fluoride under hydrothermal conditions in the presence of CC, followed by calcination at 450 °C under N2 atmosphere (Fig. 2 a). NiNS/CC was obtained by treatment of the obtained NiONS/CC at 500 °C under H2/N2 (v/v, 10/90) atmosphere (Fig. 2a). To probe the influence of Ni content in NiNS/CC on the electrocatalytic activity, a series of NiNS/CC samples were prepared with varied Ni loading levels. The investigated NiNS/CC serial samples were respectively denoted as NiNS/CC-0 (a blank sample without Ni loading), NiNS/CC-1 (1.91 mgNi cm−2), NiNS/CC-2 (3.53 mgNi cm−2), and NiNS/CC-3 (5.67 mgNi cm−2) base on inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) analysis. The morphology of Ni-based samples was initially analyzed with scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). SEM images of NiONS/CC-2 shows stacked brick-like NiO nanosheet array densely and fully assembled on the CC surface (Fig. 2b–c). The TEM analysis of NiONS-2 further confirms its brick-like nanosheet morphology (Fig. 2d). The lattice spacing of NiONS-2 was determined as 0.239 nm based on the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) characterization, which is indexed to the (200) plane of NiO. SEM images of NiNS/CC-2 exhibit a stacked nanosheet structure which densely, fully and homogeneously covers every nanofiber of CC (Fig. 2f–g). These typical 2D-nanosheets stand on the surface of CC nanofiber in a highly cross-linked style, forming a 3D and open network with a hierarchical architecture. NiNS/CC-2 can thus well take advantage of the excellent conductivity of CC. On the other hand, the thin-layered nanosheet morphology of NiNS/CC-2 possesses high specific surface area, can sufficiently and homogeneously expose its surface-active site. Accordingly, these ordered and hierarchical architecture can efficiently provide porous channels for electron communication between NiNS and CC. The TEM images of NiNS/CC-2 show a thickness of 34 nm for the thin-layered nanosheet with lattice fringes of 0.245 nm, corresponding to the (111) lattice plane of metallic Ni (Fig. 2h–i). SEM energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping of NiNS/CC-2 demonstrates that Ni, O, and C elements are distributed uniformly throughout the nanosheet (Fig. 2n–q). Finally, NiNS/CC-1 exhibits almost same architecture with the NiNS/CC-2 (Fig. 2j–l); moreover, the observed lattice fringes of NiNS/CC-1 for Ni species are same with those of NiNS/CC-2 (Fig. 2m). NiNS/CC serial samples were then investigated with X-ray diffraction (XRD). For NiNS/CC-0, a broad diffraction signal at 25.9° is assigned as graphitic carbon in CC (Fig. 3 a). NiNS/CC samples with various Ni contents all exhibit three characteristic signals at 44.5°, 51.8° and 76.4°, which are respectively indexed to the plane reflections from (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes of metallic Ni (JCPDF file No. 04-0850). As expected, the intensities of the Ni(0) phase in the NiNS/CC serial samples increase with Ni content. The XRD patterns of NiNS/CC and NiONS/CC were further compared in Fig. 3b. Four typical peaks were observed at 37.2°, 43.3°, 62.9° and 75.4° for the NiONS/CC-2 sample, respectively corresponding to four crystal planes (111), (200), (220) and (311) of NiO (JCPDF File No. 47-1049). Therefore, our XRD characterizations demonstrate the successful reduction of Ni(II) species in NiONS/CC to give Ni(0) species in NiNS/CC under H2 atmosphere. Surface composition and chemical state of NiONS/CC-2 and NiNS/CC-2 were finally characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The XPS survey of both NiONS/CC-2 and NiNS/CC-2 samples demonstrated the presence of Ni, C, O and F elements (Fig. S1a, Supporting Information). The observed F element was presumably originated from ammonium fluoride during sample preparation [55]. The O 1s XPS of NiONS/CC-2 (Fig. 3c) was deconvolved into three signals at the binding energies of 529.5 eV (lattice oxygen of NiO), 531.0 eV [hydroxide peak of Ni(OH)2] and 532.2 eV (physiosorbed water or oxygen bonded to adventitious carbon) with NiO as predominant species on the surface [56,57]. For NiNS/CC-2 sample, its O 1s XPS was very close to those of the NiONS/CC-2 with, however, Ni(OH)2 as the major surface species. The Ni 2p XPS of NiONS/CC-2 were fitted into two signals at the binding energies of 855.7 eV (indexed to Ni 2p 3/2) and 873.7 eV (assigned as Ni 2p 1/2), corresponding to Ni(OH)2 species (Fig. 3d). Moreover, two characteristic peaks at 854.2 eV (Ni 2p 3/2) and 871.8 eV (Ni 2p 1/2) were detected from NiONS/CC-2 surface, demonstrating the presence of NiO species. In the case of NiNS/CC-2, two signals at 851.1 eV (Ni 2p 3/2) and 869.2 eV (Ni 2p 1/2) were additionally observed, which corresponds to Ni0 species, further confirming the successful Ni(II)-to-Ni(0) reduction [48,58]. The observed Ni(II) species on the NiNS/CC-2 surface is presumably related to reoxidation of Ni(0) to Ni(II) upon the exposure of NiNS/CC-2 to air [59,60]. 3.2 Screening of electrocatalysts Electrochemical synthesis of 4a via oxidative cyclocondensation of 1a with 2a was then investigated in a single-chamber electrolyser by using a two-electrode configuration (Fig. 4 a). Various developed electrocatalysts were respectively examined as anodes with Pt as cathode and KI as electrolyte in CH3OH/H2O solvent (Fig. 4b). The oxidative cyclocondensation was initially performed with commercially available CC, affording a mixture of 3a (20% yield), 4a (35% yield), and 2-furoic acid (10% yield; 7, Fig. 4a) with 1a conversion around 85%. 3a was presumably obtained by direct electrocatalytic oxidation of 1a over the surface of CC anode. Subsequent cyclocondensation of 3a with 2a led to 4a formation; while, consecutive electrocatalytic oxidation of 3a on the CC surface resulted in its cleavage of C−C bond to give 7 (Fig. 4a). In addition to 1a oxidation, electro-oxidative self-cyclocondensation of 2a competitively occurred over CC surface under the investigated conditions, giving 65% yield (based on 2a) of 2,3-diaminophenazine (8, Fig. 4a). Generally, very complicated reaction network with low selectivity of the desired 4a was observed from pristine CC; therefore, two-equivalent 2a to 1a was used to shift the reaction to 4a side. In the case of Pt, a significantly increased 4a selectivity (82%) was observed with, however, a moderate 1a conversion rate (50%). Meanwhile, Pt can suppress 8 formation (49% yield). In contrast, NiONS/CC exhibited high 1a conversion (90%) with moderate yields of 4a (50%, based on 1a) and 8 (58%, based on 2a). NiNS/CC-2 was obtained by NiONS/CC reduction under H2/N2 atmosphere, thus showing a rich metallic Ni species on the sample surface. Finally, NiNS/CC-2 displayed almost full conversion of 1a (>99%) with quantitative 4a yield (95%), suggesting its excellent catalytic performance for 4a formation. In addition to its excellent selectivity (96%) towards 4a formation, the electrocatalytic 2a-to-8 transformation was significantly inhibited over NiNS/CC-2 surface, by yielding 20% yield of 8 (based on 2a). Our electrocatalyst screening thus suggested superior activity and selectivity of NiNS/CC-2 over CC and Pt for 4a synthesis. In this regard, NiNS/CC serial catalysts with various Ni content were further investigated for 4a synthesis (Fig. 4c). A blank catalyst of NiNS/CC sample without Ni loading (denoted as NiNS/CC-0) demonstrated moderate 1a conversion with low 4a yield. Then, increasing Ni loading level in the NiNS/CC samples from 1.91 mgNi cm−2 (NiNS/CC-1) to 3.53 mgNi cm−2 (NiNS/CC-2) led to an enhanced 1a conversions as well as 4a yields. Full 1a conversion (>99%) with quantitative 4a yield (95%) were observed with NiNS/CC-2. Finally, further increasing Ni loading level to 5.67 mgNi cm−2 (NiNS/CC-3) resulted in unchanged 4a yield (95%). Therefore, the NiNS/CC-2 with an optimal Ni loading is the most active electrocatalyst for 1a/2a-to-4a transformation in terms of 4a yield and selectivity. The effect of voltage on the oxidative cyclocondensation revealed that 4a yield enhanced with voltage up to 2.0 V (Fig. 4d), further raising voltage led to a reduced 4a yield due to quick cleavage of the C−C bond in the in-situ formed 3a to give 7 (Fig. 4a). Finally, the effect of reaction solvent on the electrocatalytic reaction was performed (Fig. 4e). A combination of H2O and polar protic solvents, such as MeOH/H2O and EtOH/H2O, can effectively promote the reaction by affording quantitative 4a yields. In contrast, 4a yield remarkably reduced to 70% in pure MeOH, presumably due to excellent solubility of KI in H2O. When MeCN/H2O, 1,4-dioxane/H2O and hexafluoroisopropanol (HFIP)/H2O were used as solvents, the resulting 4a yields were very low (7∼11%), suggesting promotion effect of polar protic solvent on the reaction. Therefore, MeOH/H2O is the best solvent for 4a formation under the investigated conditions. While, negligible 4a yields (7∼11%) were obtained from MeCN/H2O, 1,4-dioxane/H2O and HFIP/H2O. 3.3 Reaction pathway To probe the reaction mechanism of the oxidative cyclocondensation, the pathway of NiNS/CC-2 promoted 1a/2a-to-4a transformation was further explored. As shown in Fig. 5 a, the oxidative cyclocondensation pathway (path i) may presumably involve an initial electro-oxidation of 1a (α-hydroxyketone) to 3a (1,2-diketone, path ii), followed by cyclocondensation of in-situ formed 3a with 2a to give 4a (path iii). Initially, the oxidative cyclocondensation pathway (path i, Fig. 5a) was examined for direct 1a/2a-to-4a conversion, the resulting gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC−MS) characterization was in-situ performed against the reaction time for this transformation. Fig. 5b shows the obtained product-distribution profiles versus reaction time. The 1a conversion steadily increased to 99% at a reaction time of 4 h; meanwhile, 4a yield smoothly enhanced to 94% as the maximum value. In contrast, 3a yields slightly fluctuated between 2% and 5% without any significant accumulations at this stage. Therefore, 3a was suggested as the reaction “intermediate”, the electro-oxidation of 1a for 3a formation was presumably the rate-determining step. While, subsequent cyclocondensation of 3a with 2a should perform readily and quickly, thus inhibiting the accumulation of 3a concentration during the tandem reaction. Notably, a directly oxidative self-cyclocondensation of 2a was also observed on the surface of NiNS/CC-2 anode, giving 25% yield of 8 (based on 2a, path iv, Fig. 5a). In fact, electrocatalytic oxidation for 1a-to-3a transformation and 2a-to-8 conversion parallelly and competitively occurred on the NiNS/CC-2 surface with 3a formation as the predominant reaction pathway (will be discussed below). To understand the effect of oxidation and condensation steps on the 4a formation, the direct 1a/2a-to-4a conversion was decomposed into two steps of 1a-oxidation and 3a/2a-condensation reactions in a one-pot process. That is, electro-oxidation of 1a to 3a was performed with NiNS/CC-2 catalyst (path ii, Fig. 5a); while, cyclocondensation of 3a with newly-added 2a was subsequently carried out without electrolysis and catalyst separation (path iii, Fig. 5a). Fig. 5c plots the resulting reaction curves against reaction time for the two-step sequential electro-oxidation–cyclocondensation reactions in a one-pot process. NiNS/CC-2-catalyzed electro-oxidation of 1a resulted in the smoothly formation of 3a with a maximum yield of 96% at 4 h. Subsequent loading of 2a in the absence of electrolysis gave 4a via cyclocondensation, affording 4a in the overall yield of 89% within 1 h. Prolonging the cyclocondensation time to 4 h gave 94% yield of 4a. The results of two-step in a one-pot reaction further confirmed the rate-determining step of the electro-oxidation process by using NiNS/CC-2 catalyst (path ii, Fig. 5a). Notably, 2a-to-8 electro-oxidation was unobserved, thus affording high selectivity of 4a product. Notably, the nucleophilicity of aromatic 1,2-diamine is highly pKb-dependent in the cyclocondensation, and the reactivity of aromatic 1,2-diamine is correlated to the electronic effect of the substituted group in most case. The electronic effect of the substituted group on the aromatic ring of 1,2-diamine was then investigated for the electro-oxidative cyclocondensation. 4-Fluoro-1,2-phenylenediamine (2h, Fig. 5a), bearing a strong electron-withdrawing group, was selected to probe the reaction. Initially, a one-pot reaction of direct 1a/2h-to-4h transformation (path i, Fig. 5a) was examined, and the resulting product-distribution curves versus reaction time were plotted as shown in Fig. 5d. Both 1a conversion and 4h yield very slowly increased with reaction time, and respectively reached maximum values of 50% for 1a conversion and 44% for 4h yield at the reaction time of 7 h. Meanwhile, 3a yield kept almost constant at 4% without any significant changes at this stage. Similarly, both 1a-electro-oxidation and 2h-electro-oxidation were observed on the NiNS/CC-2 surface. However, 2h-oxidation was very complicated and the resulting products were unidentified. We believe that strong adsorptions of 2h and its oxidized products on the NiNS/CC-2 surface inhibit the electro-catalytic oxidation process of 1a, resulting in a significantly reduced 1a conversion. The above assumption was subsequently confirmed by the two-step 1a/2h-to-4h conversion in a one-pot process (paths ii and iii, Fig. 5a). A quantitative 3a yield (96%) was observed during the electrocatalytic oxidation of 1a with the reaction time of 4h (Fig. 5e). A consecutive cyclocondensation of 3a with freshly-added 2h afforded 87% yield of 4h within 4 h in the absence of electrolysis. Evidently, the two-step in one-pot process can efficiently increase the yield of desired quinoxaline product by eliminating competitive electro-oxidation of 1,2-diamine. 3.4 Mechanism investigation Controlled experiments were then performed to probe the reaction mechanism of the 1a-to-3a electro-oxidation (Scheme 1 a). Initially, radical scavengers such as 5,5-dimethyl-l-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO, path b) and 1,1-diphenylethylene (DPE, path c) were respectively and additionally added into the reaction system under the standard condition (path a), 3a yields only dropped slightly. The above radical scavenger experiments thus suggested that the radical species was presumably not the key intermediate to push the 1a-to-3a transformation [61]. Notably, no reaction was observed when stoichiometric amounts of I2 were loaded into the reaction mixture in the absence of electricity (path d), which demonstrates that the true active species for 1a-to-3a oxidation was hypervalent iodine species ([In+], n = 1, 5, 7) rather than I2. To investigate the specific valence state of the [In+], KIO3 ([I5+], path e) and KIO4 ([I7+], path f) were respectively probed as oxidants for the 1a-to-3a oxidation without electricity, again, 3a product was unobserved. For comparison purpose, KI in CH3OH/H2O was initially electrolyzed under standard conditions followed by addition of 1a (path g); unfortunately, the desired 3a was still undetectable. Therefore, the proposed [In+] should be highly reactive, in-situ formed on the NiNS/CC-2 anode, and in-situ reduced by 1a with very limited life-time. Previous research demonstrated reactive and unstable IO− ([I+]) species as oxidant for various organic transformations. Moreover, IO− can be in-situ generated by I−-oxidation with tert-butyl alcohol hydroperoxide (TBHP) at ambient temperature. Inspired by the above literature-results, TBHP and in-situ formed IO− were respectively examined as the oxidants for the 1a-to-3a oxidation in the absence of electricity. Direct treatment 1a with excess amount of TBHP failed to yield 3a (path h), indicating unactive TBHP towards the 1a-to-3a oxidation. In contrast, when TBHP and 1a were stirred in the presence of KI, 60% yield of 3a was finally obtained after 2 h (path i). [I+] was thus suggested as the key active species for the 1a-to-3a oxidation by in-situ electro-oxidation of I−. Scheme 1b thus depicts plausible mechanism for electro-oxidative cyclocondensation of 1a/2a to 4a over NiNS/CC on the basis of the above results. Surface Ni(III) species (NiOOH) is initially formed from Ni(OH)2 by anodic oxidation. I− anion then undergoes two consecutive I−-to-[I0] and [I0]-to-[I+] single-electron-transfer electro-oxidation processes to finally give the [I+], which is well coupled with the NiOOH-to-Ni(OH)2 single-electron-transfer reduction on the NiNS/CC surface (Fig. S5f, Supporting Information) [61,62]. Ni(III) species functions as electron transfer mediator for I−-to-[I0] and [I0]-to-[I+] electro oxidation. The resulting Ni(II) species is, again, oxidized to Ni(III) species at the prevailed anodic potential, leading to regeneration of catalytic active Ni(III) species. The above assumption can be confirmed by the following experiments. The Ni 2p XPS analysis of the recovered NiNS/CC-2 suggested the presence of NiOOH species at 874.7 eV (Ni 2p 1/2) and 856.9 eV (Ni 2p 3/2) (Fig. S6c, Supporting Information). The oxidation potentials of I−/I0 (0.41 V vs. Ag/AgCl) and I0/I+ (0.94 V vs. Ag/AgCl) can be roughly obtained from the cyclic voltammogram (CV) plots of KI−CH3OH/H2O system with and without addition of 1a (Fig. 6 f). Subsequent iodination between the [I+] species and 1a affords O-iodo intermediate (9) [63]. Intramolecular elimination of HI from molecule 9 generates 1,2-diketone 3a. Meanwhile, H+ reduction on Pt electrode affords H2 on the cathode surface. H2 product is actually derived from electrocatalytic dehydrogenation of 1a instead of H2O splitting. Therefore, the resulting pH values were almost unchanged during the 1a/2a-to-4a transformation (Table S1, Supporting Information). Finally, intermolecular cyclocondensation of 3a with 2a yields 4a and two molecules of H2O. Therefore, KI acts as supporting electrolyte as well as the redox mediator for NiNS/CC-promoted electrochemical oxidation reaction, in which I− is presumably regenerated as HI [64–66]. According to literature and aforementioned results [67,68], Scheme 1c shows proposed mechanism for electro-oxidative self-cyclocondensation of 2a to 8. 2a was initially oxidized on the surface of anode to afford 1,2-phenylenediamine cation radical species (12), which consecutively and step-by-step loses protons and electrons to form a key intermediate of cyclohexa-3,5-diene-1,2-diimine (14). p-Imino imine intermediate (16) is obtained by electrophilic attack of another 2a molecule to 14 via 1,4-conjugate addition, followed by oxidative dehydrogenation of 15. Finally, cyclization of 16 and oxidative dehydrogenation of 17 generate the observed 8. Meanwhile, H+ was reduced to H2 on the cathode of Pt electrode. Open-circuit potential (OCP) measurements were then used to probe the changes of organic adsorbents in the inner Helmholtz layer of the NiNS/CC-2 anode. OCP generally reflects the potential difference between electrode and electrolyte, which is directly related to the driving force of the electrochemical reaction. A higher OCP of the electrode corresponds to its higher oxidizing or reducing nature with higher activity in the electrochemical reaction. A significant decrease in OCP thus suggests strong adsorption of substrate on the electrode [69,70]. As shown in Fig. 6, the OCP curve of KI showed the largest decrease of 0.350 V, which is much greater than those of 1a (0.108 V) and 2a (0.149 V), suggesting a predominant I−-to-[I+] electro-oxidation in the Helmholtz layer of the NiNS/CC-2 anode. In addition, the OCP of 1a+2a+KI mixture (0.363 V) is very close to the value of KI used alone, further indicating that KI is the main adsorbed species. The OCP measurements thus demonstrated a preferential adsorption of KI on the anode surface for I−-to-[I+] electro-oxidation, which significantly inhibits electro-oxidative cyclocondensation of 2a-to-8 and thus shifts the reaction to the KI-mediated 1a-to-3a oxidation. Constant voltage was used for the electrocatalytic reaction, thus leading to a variable current density during the reaction. The plot of current density against reaction time slightly fluctuated at around 2.4 mA cm−2 over the NiNS/CC-2 anode (Fig. S4d, Supporting Information). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was then used to investigate the electrocatalytic kinetics and electrode/electrolyte interface characteristics of the electrodes [69,71]. Fig. 6b shows the fitted Nyquist plots from the corresponding EIS measurements of NiNS/CC serial anodes with Ni loading range 0 ∼ 5.67 mgNi cm−2 at 2.0 V potential. The smallest semicircle radius was observed with the NiNS/CC-2 (3.53 mgNi cm−2), suggesting its lowest interfacial charge transfer resistance ( R c t ) and best electronic conductivity, which is conducive to the rapid charge transfer process for this anodic oxidation. KI has much smaller semicircle radius on the NiNS/CC-2 than those of 1a and 2a (Fig. 6c), which is attributed to a preferential adsorption and oxidation of KI on the anode surface. 1a presents a steep straight line, indicating a great resistance for its anodization. The Nyquist plots of NiNS/CC-2 in the potential range from OCP to 2.5 V demonstrated significantly decreased radius of the semicircle with the increased potential (Fig. 6d), suggesting decreased R c t and facilitated charge-transfer kinetics with the potential. The resulting Bode phase diagram showed a peak in the low-frequency region (below 10 Hz), the height of the peak decreased with the potential and moved towards the higher frequency region (Fig. 6e). Therefore, the initial kinetic stage involved I− adsorption on the NiNS/CC-2 surface, leading to an uneven charge distribution as well as a slow appearance of [I+] species at the electrode interface in the low-frequency region at low potential. The above EIS analyses suggested excellent electronic conductivity of NiNS/CC-2 to facilitate the electron-transfer kinetics of I− adsorption and oxidation. The KI-mediated 1a-to-3a oxidation on the NiNS/CC-2 surface was further confirmed by CV measurements. CV curves of pure CH3OH/H2O solvent with and without addition of 1a exhibited negligible deviations (Fig. S1b, Supporting Information), suggesting unobserved anodic 1a-to-3a oxidation in the range of −0.7∼1.4 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) in the CH3OH/H2O solvent [72]. In contrast, the CV of KI in CH3OH/H2O solution showed obvious anodic peak currents (0.41 and 0.94 V) and cathodic peak currents (−0.24 and 0.63 V) corresponding to redox system of the I−-to-[I+] (Fig. 6f) [61,73]. When 1a was added into the KI−CH3OH/H2O solution, a strong catalytic current was detected with enhanced oxidation/reduction current peaks, which demonstrates a key role of KI as a mediator for the 1a-to-3a oxidation. Notably, I− can be readily regenerated in the time scale of the CV scan [74,75]. Finally, the mechanism of reaction selectivity was further probed based on reaction kinetics of the anodic oxidation. Evidently, 1a-to-3a electro oxidation (Scheme 1b) and 2a-to-8 electro-oxidative cyclocondensation (Scheme 1c) competitively and parallelly proceed on the anode surface, thus determining the product distribution and reaction selectivity. Fig. 6g shows initial 3a formation rates over various electrocatalyst for the 1a-to-3a electrooxidation, demonstrating a slightly high initial formation rate (9.6 mM h−1) of 3a product over NiNS/CC-2 when compared with those from CC and Pt. In the case of electro-oxidative cyclocondensation of 1a/2a-to-4a, both 1a-to-4a conversion (Scheme 1b) and 2a-to-8 transformation (Scheme 1c) were observed over the investigated electrocatalysts. NiNS/CC-2 exhibited the highest 4a formation rate (5.8 mM h−1) as well as 3a formation rate (3.4 mM h−1, Fig. 6h). Notably, 3a formation rate (3.4 mM h−1) over NiNS/CC-2 is almost 6 times higher than those from CC (0.6 mM h−1) and 3 times higher than those from Pt (1.1 mM h−1). Moreover, NiNS/CC-2 shows the lowest initial formation rate of 8 (1.8 mM h−1) if compared with those from CC (3.6 mM h−1) and Pt (2.4 mM h−1). The control experiments were also performed with the oxidative self-cyclocondensation of 2a to 8. As expected, KI cannot function as oxidant to promote the 2a-to-8 transformation in the absence of electricity (Fig. S3a, Supporting Information). While, I2 and KI+TBHP can slightly push the 2a-to-8 transformation with negligible 8 yield (5∼15%). In the case of electrochemical 2a-to-8 transformation with KI as the electrolyte, 8 yield significantly raised with enhanced voltage (Fig. S3b). Moreover, TBABF4 showed similar effect on the 2a-to-8 transformation as an electrolyte when compared with the KI (Fig. S3c). Therefore, we believe that the electrochemical 2a-to-8 transformation was mainly driven by electricity. Moreover, both TBABF4 and KI generally acted as electrolytes, additional promotion from KI was very limited. Based on the above kinetic analysis and mechanism investigation, the advantage of the developed NiNS/CC-2 can be attributed to its quick promotion effect on the 1a-to-3a electro-oxidation (Scheme 1b). Meanwhile, the electro-oxidative self-cyclocondensation for 2a-to-8 transformation (Scheme 1c) can be significantly inhibited on the NiNS/CC-2 surface, thus leading to 4a formation in a selective and efficient way. 3.5 Scope of the electrochemical synthesis With the optimized reaction conditions in hand, a variety of α-hydroxyketones (1) and 1,2-diamines (2) were tested to determine the generality and limitation of the method (Fig. 7 ). Initially, a direct 1/2-to-4 transformation in a one-pot process was applied for the electrochemical synthesis of quinoxaline. In the cases of α-hydroxyketones (1), in addition to 1a, benzoin (1b) can well proceed with the reaction by affording the corresponding 2,3-diphenylquinoxaline (4o) in excellent yield. However, introduction of electron-donating substituent (methyl, 1c) on the phenyl ring led to the reduced 2,3-di-p-tolylquinoxaline (4p) yield. This observation is presumably attributed to the decreased electrophilicity of the in-situ generated 1,2-di-p-tolylethane-1,2-dione (3c, 1,2-dicarbonyl), thus resulting in a reduced 4p yield. In contrast, 81% yield of 4p can be obtained by a two-step in one-pot process, in which electro-oxidation of 1c and cyclocondensation of 3c/2a were separated. In addition to α-hydroxyketones (1), various 1,2-diamines such as aliphatic (2b−c), heterocyclic (2d), and aromatic 1,2-diamines (2a, 2e−n) were systematically examined for the reaction. The electrocatalytic reactions of 1a with aliphatic ethylenediamine (2b) quantitatively yielded pyrazine (4b) product. The formation of 4b suggested the presence of NiNS/CC-catalyzed an initially electro-oxidative cyclocondensation of 1a with 2b to give a 5,6-di(2-furanyl)-2,3-dihydropyrazine intermediate, followed by a NiNS/CC-promoted electro-oxidative dehydrogenation of dihydropyrazine to afford 4b. In the case of 1,2-diaminocyclohexane (2c), the electro-oxidative cyclocondensation led to a mixture of tetrahydroquinoxaline (4ca) and hexahydroquinoxaline (4cb) products, further suggesting the presence of NiNS/CC-promoted electro-oxidative dehydrogenation of 4cb for the construction of aromatic ring in 4ca. Heterocyclic 2,3-diaminopyridine (2d) can also well proceed with the electrocatalytic reaction by affording 2,3-di(2-furanyl)pyrido[2,3-b]pyrazine (4d). Aromatic 1,2-diamines, bearing electron-donating groups (−CH3, −2CH3 and −OCH3; 2e–g), were well tolerated under the investigated conditions, producing the desired quinoxalines (4e–g) in excellent yields (92–99%). In contrast, introduction of electron-withdrawing groups (−F, −Cl, −2Cl, −Br, −COOCH3, −COPh; 2h–m) on the phenyl ring resulted in significantly reduced quinoxalines yields (23–74%, 4 h–m). Notably, no product was detected from the electrochemical reaction of 4-nitro-1,2-phenylenediamine (2n), due to its strong electron-withdrawing nitro group. These electron-withdrawing groups on the phenyl ring of 1,2-diamines may presumably reduce their nucleophilicity/basicity and inhibit their nucleophilic attack to the in-situ formed 1,2-diketone 3a. Finally, excellent to good yields of the desired quinoxalines (4d, 4h–m; 93−80%) can still be obtained by the two-step in one-pot process, in which the two step reactions of 1a-electrooxidation and 3a/2-cyclocondensation were separated in a one-pot process. Under such conditions, prolonged and specified cyclocondensation times were beneficial to the rate-determining step of the cyclocondensation. Moreover, stepwisely/freshly-added 2 at the cyclocondensation stage in the absence of electricity can completely eliminate the electro-oxidation of 2, thus enhancing the yield and selectivity of the desired 4 in the complicated tandem network. To semi-quantitatively understand the above electronic effect of substituents on the 2a towards the cyclization step, Hammett correlation was investigated for the cyclocondensation of 1a with various 2 [76,77]. A mixture of equimolar quantities of 2a and 4-R-substituted 2a (1:1 M ratio) was prepared as a mixed 1,2-diamine, where substituent group R is −Me, −OMe, −F, −COOCH3, and −NO2. An equimolar of 1a to the mixed 1,2-diamine was then added into the cyclocondensation system in the absence of electricity under the investigated conditions. The ratios of reaction rates ( k R / k H ) for various 4-R-substituted 2 ( k R ) and 2a ( k H ) were obtained by GC analysis. Fig. S1c exhibits the resulting Hammett plot of the l o g ( k R / k H ) values against the standard composite σ constants. σ constants were obtained from literature, representing the effect of the electron density on the phenyl ring. A linear plot between l o g ( k R / k H ) and σ affords Hammett equation [ l o g ( k R / k H ) = ρ σ + b ], yielding a slope as the characteristic ρ constant of the reaction. The resulting negative value of the ρ (−0.62) suggests nucleophilic feature of 2a in the cyclocondensation; moreover, enhanced electron density in the aromatic ring of the 2 promotes the rate-determining step of the nucleophilic addition. 3.6 NiNS/CC promoted 1a-to-3a electro-oxidation As shown in Fig. 8 a, a tandem 1a-to-4a transformation involved NiNS/CC-2-promoted 1a-to-3a electro-oxidation and cyclocondensation of 3a with 2a. Therefore, the electrocatalytic performance of NiNS/CC-2 was further investigated as a working electrode for the electro-oxidation of 1a to 3a. The electrochemical investigations were carried out in a standard three-electrode configuration and various reaction parameters on the 1a-to-3a electro-oxidation were investigated. The effect of Ni content in NiNS/CC on the 1a-to-3a electro-oxidation revealed that both 1a conversion and 3a yield increased with the Ni loading level with NiNS/CC-2 (3.53 mgNi cm−2) and NiNS/CC-3 (5.67 mgNi cm−2) as the most active electrocatalysts (Fig. 8b). Notably, NiNS/CC-2 also exhibited the highest Faradaic efficiency (FE, 50%) for 3a formation. In contrast, a significantly reduced FE (22%) was observed with the NiNS/CC-3. These results can presumably be attributed to quick oxidation of KI and/or oxygen evolution reaction (OER) over NiNS/CC-3 surface under the reaction conditions. Therefore, the influence of KI concentration on the 1a-to-3a electro-oxidation was further investigated (Fig. 8c). Both 1a conversion and 3a yield generally increased smoothly with KI concentration. However, the resulting FE decreased steady with the increased KI concentration, suggesting the co-existence of I−/[I+] redox during the 1a-to-3a electro-oxidation. We believe that increased KI concentration leads to enhanced current density, thus accelerating I−/[I+] redox process and reducing FE. Under such condition, KI functioned as electrolyte as well as a mediator for NiNS/CC-promoted 3a formation. A mixed electrolyte of tetrabutylammonium tetrafluoroborate (TBABF4) and KI with varied KI/TBABF4 ratios were used to further investigate the role of KI in electrochemical 1a-to-3a oxidation. In contrast to KI, TBABF4 is an inert organic electrolyte as a blank control group in this research, the total concentrations of KI and TBABF4 were then maintained as 40 mM to keep the same ion concentrations during the experiment. When pure TBABF4 was used as the electrolyte, the electrochemical 1a-to-3a oxidation proceeded with extremely low reaction rate as well as poor 3a-selectivity on the NiNS/CC-2 surface (Fig. S4a-b, Supporting Information) [78]. Low selectivity of 3a formation was attributed to consecutive electro catalytic oxidation of 3a via cleavage of its C−C bond to give 7 (Fig. 4a) [79]. Increasing KI/TBABF4 ratios steeply improved oxidation rate of 1a as well as 3a selectivity, which is ascribed to enhanced process of KI-mediated 1a-to-3a oxidation instead of direct 1a-to-3a oxidation on the NiNS/CC-2 surface. These results demonstrated the superiority of KI as an electrolyte and mediator for the electrochemical 1a-to-3a oxidation. The effect of KI/TBABF4 ratios on the anodic 1a-to-3a oxidation was then investigated by using the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) method. As shown in Fig. S4c, electrochemical performance of NiNS/CC-2 with the electrolyte of KI is far superior to that of TBABF4, increasing the KI/TBABF4 ratios led to enhanced electrochemical performance. The effect of electrolyte on the electro-oxidation was further performed by using various conductive salts such as KCl, KBr, KI, NaI, NH4I, and n-Bu4NI (Fig. 8d). The electrolyte KI exhibited the highest 1a conversion and 3a yield among the explored conductive salts, confirming a bifunctional role of KI as electrolyte and mediator for the electrooxidation. However, in the case of NH4I and n-Bu4NI, moderate 3a yields were observed, due to the co-existence of the electrochemical transformations of the cations (NH4 + and n-Bu4N+) into NH3 and organic amines [80]. The difference between KI and NaI on the reaction was still not fully understood at the present stage. The influence of potential on the 1a electro-oxidation suggested that 3a yield enhanced with the potential up to 1.0 V (vs. Ag/AgCl, Fig. 8e). Finally, the influence of solvent on the electro-oxidation demonstrated that a mixed MeOH/H2O solvent can effectively promote the 1a oxidation by affording quantitative 3a yield (Fig. 8f). The anodic reaction was then investigated by using LSV method to analyze the electrode performance of the NiNS/CC-2 with and without addition of 1a (20 mM). Before the measurement, the electrode was activated by a ten-time cycle of cyclic voltammetry (CV) each time at a scan rate of 50 mV s−1. As shown in Fig. 9 a, the LSV curve recorded on NiNS/CC-2 without 1a shows a 0.500 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) onset potential to reach 1 mA cm−2 current density. Moreover, NiNS/CC-2 exhibits a potential of 0.661 V(vs. Ag/AgCl) at the characteristic current density of 10 mA cm−2, corresponding to OER. After the addition of 1a (20 mM), NiNS/CC-2 only requires 0.618 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) to drive the 10 mA cm−2 current densities. These results indicated that the electrochemical oxidation of 1a is thermodynamically more favourable than the OER over NiNS/CC-2. In contrast, the anodic potential of the NiNS/CC-0, corresponding to the current density of 1 mA cm−2, changed from 0.841 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) to 0.783 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) after the addition of 1a, which suggests a key role of metallic site on the 1a-to-3a electro-oxidation (Fig. 9a). The influence of Ni content in NiNS/CC on the electrocatalytic activity was then investigated for 1a oxidation by using LSV (Fig. 9b). NiNS/CC-2, again, showed a minimum over potential about 0.618 V (vs. Ag/AgCl, corresponding to a current density of 10 mA cm−2). In contrast, a maximum over potential of 0.783 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) was observed with NiNS/CC-0. These observations suggested that the NiNS/CC-2 catalyst with an optimal Ni loading level can effectively reduce the over potential for 1a oxidation. In most case, the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) of electro catalyst is associated with the number of active centres and is linear to its double-layer capacitance ( C d l ). Therefore, the electrochemical C d l of serial NiNS/CC and NiONS/CC-2 electrocatalysts were measured by CV within the non-Faraday region (potential window, 0.20–0.25 V vs. Ag/AgCl). Fig. S5a-e (Supporting Information) shows CV curves of serial NiNS/CC and NiONS/CC-2 catalysts at various scan rates (20–70 mV s−1). All samples show typical rectangular features, indicating an ideal behavior of electric double-layer capacitor at different scan rates. Fig. 9c shows the resulting correlation between the current density difference ( j a − j c ) and scan rate based on Fig. S5a-e. While, Fig. 9d exhibits the obtained C d l as the slopes of the curves by transforming the ( j a - j c ) (Fig. 9c) into the corresponding current density. Evidently, NiNS/CC-2 shows the highest C d l (0.59 mF cm−2) for 1a-to-3a electro-oxidation among the investigated samples (Fig. 9d), indicating the presence of abundant electrocatalytic active site on the nanostructured NiNS/CC-2 surface. Generally, the C d l (0.53 mF cm−2) of NiNS/CC-3 is very close to that of NiNS/CC-2, suggesting a comparable catalytic performance between NiNS/CC-2 and NiNS/CC-3 for 1a-to-3a electro-oxidation (Fig. 8b). Finally, a low C d l (0.21 mF cm−2) value was observed with NiNS/CC-0, corresponding to its moderate activity for 1a-to-3a electro-oxidation (Fig. 8b). NiNS/CC-2 shows much higher 3a yields toward the 1a-to-3a electro-oxidation if compared with the NiONS/CC-2. In fact, NiOOH species was also detected on the surface of recovered NiONS/CC-2 (Fig. S6g). However, NiNS/CC-2 was obtained by calcination under an atmospheric H2/N2 at 500 °C, which leads to reconstruction of metallic Ni on the NiNS/CC-2 surface. Therefore, NiNS/CC-2 (0.59 mF cm−2, Fig. 9d) shows much higher C d l than those of NiONS/CC-2 (0.46 mF cm−2), suggesting higher ECSA as well as electrochemical performance of the NiNS/CC-2 over NiONS/CC-2 for the 1a-to-3a electro-oxidation. Moreover, the Ni(II)-to-Ni(III) oxidation-peak potential of NiNS/CC-2 on the CV plot is 0.31 V (vs. Ag/AgCl), which is much lower than that of NiONS/CC-2 (0.54 V vs. Ag/AgCl) (Fig. S5f). The above C d l and CV analyses further suggested enhanced electrochemical performance of the NiNS/CC-2 due to its reconstruction. Similar shapes between oxidation and reduction peaks of the NiNS/CC-2 further demonstrated its excellent reversibility for nickel species during the redox process (Fig. S5f). 3.7 Catalyst reusability Finally, reusability of the NiNS/CC-2 electrode was examined by an eight-time consecutive run. Each time, the NiNS/CC-2 electrode was thoroughly cleaned with ethanol/deionized water, and then directly used for the next run with freshly loaded reaction mixture. As shown in Fig. 10 , an evidently decreased 4a yield was observed from 90% to 80%, which can be attributed to a partial falling-off of the NiNS component from the CC under the reaction conditions of vigorous stirring and long-time electrolysis. Our ICP-OES analysis confirmed slightly reduced Ni content from 3.53 mgNi cm−2 for fresh catalyst to 3.49 mgNi cm−2 for the recovered one after the eight-time recycling. Notably, the recovered NiNS/CC-2 showed almost the same XRD and SEM characterization results as the fresh one (Fig. S6), suggesting well-maintained crystal framework and surface composition of the recovered catalyst. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we have demonstrated Ni-promoted electro-oxidative cyclocondensations of furoin with 1,2-phenylenediamines for the synthesis of a variety of biomass-based quinoxalines (16 examples) in 97∼80% yields. The reaction pathway of the electrochemical furoin-to-quinoxaline transformation involves a tandem reaction of Ni-promoted I−-to-[I+] electro-oxidation, [I+]-induced furoin-to-furil oxidation, and furil/1,2-phenylenediamine cyclocondensation. The high performance of Ni catalyst is ascribed to its promotion effect on quick and selective I−-to-[I+] electro-oxidation, thus triggering a [I+]-mediated furoin oxidation. In contrast, the competitive reaction of direct 1,2-phenylenediamine oxidation is significantly suppressed on the anodic Ni surface. KI functions as both redox mediator and supporting electrolyte, selectively facilitating furoin oxidation. This research thus highlights a sustainable way for the productions of high value-added aromatic N-heterocycles by electro-catalytic transformation of biomass-based compounds with earth-abundant transition-metal catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Electrochemical valorization of biomass to aromatic N-heterocycles is a pioneering field and an eco-friendly synthetic strategy. Herein, electro-oxidative cyclocondensations of biomass-based furoin with 1,2-phenylenediamines are developed for quinoxalines syntheses (16 examples) in 97∼80% yields by using Ni-based electro catalyst with KI as electrolyte and mediator. The electrocatalyst is developed as Ni-nanosheets densely assembled on a knitted carbon cloth with a hierarchical 3D-open network. The electrochemical furoin-to-quinoxaline transformation involves a tandem reaction of Ni-promoted I−-to-[I+] electro-oxidation, [I+]-induced furoin-to-furil oxidation, and furil/1,2-phenylenediamine cyclocondensation. The high performance of Ni catalyst is ascribed to its promotion effect on quick and selective I−-to-[I+] electro-oxidation, thus triggering a [I+]-mediated furoin oxidation. In contrast, the competitive reaction of direct 1,2-phenylenediamine oxidation is significantly suppressed on the anodic Ni surface. This research thus highlights a sustainable way for the productions of high value-added aromatic N-heterocycles by electro catalytic transformation of biomass-based compounds with earth-abundant transition-metal catalyst.
